intro: Aster novi-belgii var. ampliflorus, commonly known as the New York aster, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of ray and disc florets. The plant typically grows to a height of 1 to 3 feet, with lance-shaped leaves and showy purple to blue flowers that bloom in late summer to early fall. It prefers full sun to partial shade and well-drained soil, making it a suitable choice for garden landscapes. Its botanical features make it a valuable addition to both wildflower gardens and ecological restoration projects.
